text.value: for some reason this page isn't printed, like it's not showing nothing

A few things to check:
- Make sure page.js is being imported/used somewhere. Typically pages live in the `pages` directory and get automatically routed, but since this page.js file is in a nested `app/pages` directory it may not be getting picked up.
- Double check the path to page.js is correct from wherever you are trying to import/use it.
- Make sure page.js is exported properly so it can be imported. It is exporting a default function component which looks correct.
- Check if you have any custom App component that could be overriding the page rendering.
- Try simplifying page.js to just return a basic div/text directly without any components to see if something on the page renders.
- Look for any errors in the console that could indicate why the page is not rendering.
- If using SSR, make sure page.js is included in the pages that get server side rendered.
Some things to try to troubleshoot further. The key is likely making sure page.js is imported/used correctly from the right location.
well it says no usages but it's the main page so it doesn't have usage anyways

If page.js is meant to be the main page that renders at the root route, then you need to make sure it is placed in the pages directory (not a nested app/pages directory).
By default, Next.js will automatically route files in pages/ to the corresponding route. So if page.js is directly under pages/ it should render at the root route.
The reason it is saying "no usages" is because files in nested directories like app/pages won't get automatically routed - you would need to explicitly import and use them somewhere.
So in summary:
- Move page.js directly under pages/ - Remove the app/pages directory if not needed - This will make page.js the index page by default
The structure should be:
``` pages/ page.js ```
Rather than:
``` pages/
app/ pages/ page.js ```
With page.js directly under pages/, it should then render properly without needing explicit import/usage.
Let me know if that helps explain why it needs to live directly under pages/ to work as the root page!
